column1: T/F: depression is the seventh most common disorder identified and treated in general practice in Australia
column2: False, depression is the fourth most common disorder identified and treated in general practice in Australia

column1: T/F: the incidence of depressive illness is increasing
column2: True, the incidence of depressive illness is increasing across all demographic areas

column1: T/F: the Australian Mental Health Survey estimates that 4% of adults have had a depressive disorder in the past month
column2: True, the Australian Mental Health Survey estimates that 4% of adults have had a depressive disorder in the past month

column1: T/F: studies show that 3% of patients who consult a GP have clinical depression
column2: False, studies show that 7% of patients who consult a GP have clinical depression, which may coexist with an anxiety or substance abuse disorder

column1: T/F: either depressed mood or loss of pleasure from previously pleasurable activities is a requirement for the diagnosis of major depressive disorder
column2: True, at least one of depressed mood or anhedonia is required to meet DSM-IV-TR criteria for major depressive disorder

column1: T/F: Symptoms need to be present for two weeks for a diagnosis of major depressive episode according to the DSM-IV-TR classification
column2: True, symptoms need to be present for at least two weeks for a diagnosis of major depressive episode according to the DSM-IV-TR classification

column1: T/F: to make the diagnosis of depression, the core features of a depressive episode must be present every day and persistent throughout the day
column2: False, the core features of a depressive episode should be present most days for most of the day, although patients can brighten up for short period if something pleasurable occurs

column1: T/F: depression should be subdivided into endogenous and exogenous depression
column2: False, these traditional categories are no longer seen as helpful or relevant, as depression is now known to be precipitated by a complex interplay between genetic and physiological factors as well as psychosocial stressors

column1: T/F: hypersomnia and weight gain are common features in atypical depression
column2: True, atypical depression defines a set of symptoms in which hypersomnia and weight gain are common features

column1: T/F: psychotic depression is uncommon in the elderly
column2: False, psychotic depression is common in the elderly.

column1: Name 2 of the classic presentations of psychotic depression in the elderly.
column2: Nihilistic delusions, where patients believe that parts of their body have died or rotted away. Delusions of guilt and poverty, which may result in in them living in squalor or deprived social means because of this fixed belief.

column1: T/F: atypical depression is more common in women than in men
column2: True, atypical depression is more common in women than men

column1: Atypical depression is the more common presentation in patients with which associated affective disorder?
column2: Seasonal affective disorder

column1: T/F: early morning waking is a particular feature of severe melancholic depression
column2: True, waking habitually 2-3 hours before the usual time and not being able to get back to sleep is a particular feature of severe 'melancholic' depression

column1: T/F: in the differential diagnosis of depression, physical illnesses as a cause of depression need to be considered
column2: True, physical causes of depressed mood such as hypothyroidism should always be considered

column1: T/F: alcohol and illicit substance use as a cause of depression need to be considered
column2: True, while in practice it can be difficult to establish primacy of mood disturbance versus an organic contributor, physical health issues should always be assessed and treated in their own right

column1: T/F: if there is abrupt onset of a severe depression, especially in a young person, bipolar disorder should be considered
column2: True, bipolar depression is a very important differential diagnosis, as there are profound treatment implications, not least of which is that exposure to antidepressants might precipitate mania and/or cause cycle acceleration

column1: T/F: in the differential diagnosis of depression, family history is not of relevance to enquire about
column2: False, a family history, particularly of bipolar disorder, would significantly influence the differential diagnosis

column1: T/F: the presence of suicidal thoughts or plans must be ascertained in any depresssed patient
column2: True, the presence of suicidal thoughts or plans must be ascertained in any depressed patient

column1: T/F: a person's risk of suicide can be increased by discussing the risks in an open manner
column2: False, there is no good evidence that a person's risk of suicide can be increased by discussing things in an open manner

column1: T/F: alcohol and drug use is an important risk factor for suicide
column2: True, alcohol and drug use is an important risk factor for suicide

column1: T/F: factors associated with increased risk of suicidal ideation include being female, younger, unemployed or separated/divorced
column2: False, factors associated with increased risk of suicidal ideation include being male, older unemployed or separated/divorced

column1: T/F: having a chronic medical illness is an additional risk factor for the development of suicidal ideation
column2: True, having a chronic medical illness is an additional risk factor for the development of suicidal ideation

column1: T/F: all patients prescribed antidepressants should be informed about the delayed onset of effect
column2: True, though whether there is in fact a delay in onset of action remains controversial

column1: T/F: the frequency of side effects of antidepressants remains the same throughout treatment
column2: False, most side effects are early onset and time limited (about 1-2 weeks)

column1: T/F: it is important to emphasise to emphasuise the problems associated with abruptly stopping or reducing the dose of antidepressants
column2: True, it is important to emphasise the problems associated with abruptly stopping or reducing the dose of antidepressants

column1: Name 5 common symptoms abruptly discontinuing an antidepressant
column2: Nausea, dizziness, paraesthesia, anxiety and headache.

column1: T/F: withdrawal phenomena are potentially more severe with drugs that have a long half-life
column2: False, withdrawal effects are potentially more severe in drugs that have a short half-life such as paroxetine, venlafaxine and fluvoxamine

column1: T/F: recent studies have suggested that serotonergic-noradrenergic antidepressant drugs seem to have greater efficacy compared to SSRIs in depression
column2: True, recent studies have suggested that serotonergic-noradrenergic drugs, such as venlaxfaxine, mirtazapine and duloxetine, seem to have greater efficacy in depression than SSRIs

column1: Name 3 serotonergic-noradrenergic antidepressants
column2: Venlaxfaxine, mirtazapine and duloxetine

column1: T/F: tricyclic antidepressants are less favourable in treating depression, as they are less effective than the newer agents
column2: False, tricyclic antidepressants are less favourable, not because they are less effective than the newer agents, but because they are more dangerous in overdose and less well tolerated

column1: T/F: serotonin and noradrenaline reuptake inhibitors should not be prescribed to patients with severe or uncontrolled hypertension
column2: True. Blood pressure should be checked initially and regularly during treatment, particularly during dosage titration.

column1: T/F: recent data suggest SSRIs may increase the risk of GI bleeding.
column2: True, this is due to action on serotonin release from platelets. The risk is significantly increased when an SSRI is combined with an NSAID or low-dose aspirin.
